L1: # Agent Task
L2: 
L3: Task id: gcse-chemistry-8-9
L4: Task title: GCSE chemistry grade 8-9 multi-step quantitative solving
L5: Reference paper: GCSE Chemistry topic set (AQA specification-aligned, synthesized benchmark)
L6: Reference URL: https://www.aqa.org.uk/subjects/science/gcse/chemistry-8462/specification-at-a-glance
L7: 
L8: ## Objective
L9: Read the report and produce all required JSON outputs that satisfy their schemas.
L10: 
L11: ## Inputs On Disk
L12: - Report: `input/report.md`
L13: - Schemas: in `schemas/`
L14: 
L15: ## Required Outputs
L16: - `output/problem_01.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_01.schema.json`)
L17: - `output/problem_02.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_02.schema.json`)
L18: - `output/problem_03.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_03.schema.json`)
L19: - `output/problem_04.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_04.schema.json`)
L20: - `output/problem_05.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_05.schema.json`)
L21: - `output/problem_06.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_06.schema.json`)
L22: 
L23: ## Constraints
L24: - Do not invent source facts; derive calculations only from values in the report.
L25: - Use line refs as `L<number>` where required.
L26: - Where quotes are required, copy exact report snippets.
L27: - For calculation outputs, line_refs must include every report line used for equations, constants, and numeric substitutions.
L28: - Use relative paths only.
L29: - Never use absolute paths.
L30: - Never use `..` in paths.
L31: - Write valid JSON only.
L32: 
L33: ## Completion
L34: Respond with a checklist of written output files.
L35: After the checklist, stop. Do not call more tools.

toolCalls.output:
L1: # GCSE Chemistry Quantitative Challenge (Grade 8-9)
L2: 
L3: ## Provenance
L4: - Scope: GCSE Chemistry Higher Tier style quantitative problem set.
L5: - Benchmark note: This is a synthesized exam-style set aligned with AQA GCSE Chemistry (8462) quantitative topics.
L6: - Specification reference: https://www.aqa.org.uk/subjects/science/gcse/chemistry-8462/specification-at-a-glance
L7: 
L8: ## Instructions
L9: - Solve each problem from the given data only.
L10: - Use appropriate significant figures and clear working.
L11: - Use only equations/constants listed in this document.
L12: 
L13: ## Constants and Formula Reminders
L14: - Moles: n = m / Mr
L15: - Concentration: c = n / V (V in dm3)
L16: - Dilution: c1V1 = c2V2
L17: - Charge: Q = I * t
L18: - Moles of electrons: n(e-) = Q / F
L19: - Faraday constant: F = 96,500 C mol-1
L20: - At equilibrium for N2O4(g) <-> 2NO2(g): Kc = [NO2]^2 / [N2O4]
L21: - Report Kc as dimensionless (unitless).
L22: 
L23: ## Atomic / Formula Data
L24: - H = 1.0, C = 12.0, O = 16.0, S = 32.1, Ca = 40.1, Cu = 63.55
L25: - Mr(CaCO3) = 100.1
L26: - Mr(CO2) = 44.0
L27: 
L28: ## Problem P01 (Dilution)
L29: A technician transfers 25.0 cm3 of 0.200 mol dm-3 HCl into a volumetric flask and dilutes it with water to a final volume of 250.0 cm3.
L30: Find the new concentration of HCl in mol dm-3.
L31: 
L32: ## Problem P02 (Stoichiometry + Purity)
L33: Limestone sample mass = 5.00 g. The sample is 84.0% CaCO3 by mass.
L34: Reaction: CaCO3 + 2HCl -> CaCl2 + CO2 + H2O
L35: Assume acid is in excess.
L36: Calculate the maximum mass of CO2 that can be produced.
L37: 
L38: ## Problem P03 (Titration)
L39: 25.00 cm3 of H2SO4 is neutralized by 23.40 cm3 of 0.150 mol dm-3 NaOH.
L40: Reaction: H2SO4 + 2NaOH -> Na2SO4 + 2H2O
L41: Calculate the concentration of H2SO4 in mol dm-3.
L42: 
L43: ## Problem P04 (Bond Energy Estimate)
L44: Estimate deltaH for methane combustion using mean bond energies.
L45: Equation: CH4 + 2O2 -> CO2 + 2H2O
L46: Bond energies (kJ mol-1): C-H = 413, O=O = 498, C=O (in CO2) = 805, O-H = 463
L47: Use: deltaH = sum(bonds broken) - sum(bonds formed)
L48: 
L49: ## Problem P05 (Electrolysis)
L50: Copper is deposited during electrolysis of aqueous CuSO4 using inert electrodes.
L51: Current = 1.50 A, time = 30.0 min.
L52: Half-equation at cathode: Cu2+ + 2e- -> Cu
L53: Calculate the mass of copper deposited.
L54: 
L55: ## Problem P06 (Equilibrium Constant)
L56: For N2O4(g) <-> 2NO2(g), at equilibrium in a 2.00 dm3 vessel:
L57: - moles(NO2) = 0.180 mol
L58: - moles(N2O4) = 0.220 mol
L59: Calculate Kc.

steps.text:
[tool-call]\n{
  "id": "fc_0b9593a368c64bc400698f657815408194a9779896cf3ff43e",
  "type": "function_call",
  "status": "completed",
  "arguments": "{\"file_path\":\"output/problem_01.json\",\"content\":\"{\\n  \\\"problem_id\\\": \\\"P01\\\",\\n  \\\"final_answer\\\": {\\n    \\\"value\\\": 0.02,\\n    \\\"units\\\": \\\"mol dm-3\\\",\\n    \\\"precision_note\\\": \\\"Final concentration to 3 s.f. (limited by 0.200 mol dm-3 and 25.0 cm3).\\\"\\n  },\\n  \\\"method\\\": \\\"Use the dilution relationship c1V1 = c2V2. The technician dilutes 25.0 cm3 of 0.200 mol dm-3 HCl to a final volume of 250.0 cm3, so the volume increases by a factor of 250.0/25.0 = 10. Therefore the concentration decreases by the same factor: c2 = c1 × (V1/V2) = 0.200 × (25.0/250.0) = 0.200 × 0.100 = 0.0200 mol dm-3. (The cm3 units cancel in the ratio V1/V2, so no separate cm3→dm3 conversion is required when using the ratio form.)\\\",\\n  \\\"key_equations\\\": [\\n    \\\"c1V1 = c2V2\\\",\\n    \\\"c2 = c1 × (V1/V2)\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"line_refs\\\": [\\n    \\\"L16\\\",\\n    \\\"L29\\\",\\n    \\\"L30\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"checks\\\": [\\n    \\\"A tenfold increase in volume should give a tenfold decrease in concentration.\\\",\\n    \\\"0.200 mol dm-3 diluted to 10× volume gives 0.0200 mol dm-3, which is sensible.\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",
  "call_id": "call_ZSZKdw3tRe0Sz6fYvMxRJ5nq",
  "name": "write_file",

Next calculate moles using n = m/Mr. From the atomic data, Mr(CaCO3) = 40.1 + 12.0 + 3×16.0 = 100.1, so n(CaCO3) = 4.20/100.1 = 0.04196 mol ≈ 0.0420 mol. From the balanced equation CaCO3 + 2HCl → CaCl2 + CO2 + H2O, 1 mol CaCO3 produces 1 mol CO2, so n(CO2) = 0.0420 mol. Mr(CO2) = 12.0 + 2×16.0 = 44.0, so mass of CO2 = n×Mr = 0.0420 × 44.0 = 1.85 g (maximum, since acid is in excess).\\\",\\n  \\\"key_equations\\\": [\\n    \\\"n = m / Mr\\\",\\n    \\\"m(CaCO3) = sample mass × (percent/100)\\\",\\n    \\\"1 mol CaCO3 → 1 mol CO2 (from balanced equation)\\\",\\n    \\\"m = n × Mr\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"line_refs\\\": [\\n    \\\"L24\\\",\\n    \\\"L14\\\",\\n    \\\"L33\\\",\\n    \\\"L34\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"checks\\\": [\\n    \\\"Since CO2 is lighter than CaCO3, the CO2 mass should be less than 4.20 g; 1.85 g fits.\\\",\\n    \\\"Mole ratio CaCO3:CO2 is 1:1 in the given equation, so moles should match.\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",

Then n(NaOH) = c×V = 0.150 mol dm-3 × 0.02340 dm3 = 0.00351 mol. Use the balanced equation H2SO4 + 2NaOH → Na2SO4 + 2H2O: 2 mol NaOH neutralize 1 mol H2SO4, so n(H2SO4) = 0.00351/2 = 0.001755 mol. Convert acid volume: V(H2SO4) = 25.00 cm3 = 0.02500 dm3. Finally c(H2SO4) = n/V = 0.001755 / 0.02500 = 0.0702 mol dm-3.\\\",\\n  \\\"key_equations\\\": [\\n    \\\"c = n / V\\\",\\n    \\\"n = c × V\\\",\\n    \\\"n(H2SO4) = n(NaOH)/2 (from stoichiometry)\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"line_refs\\\": [\\n    \\\"L39\\\",\\n    \\\"L40\\\",\\n    \\\"L15\\\",\\n    \\\"L41\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"checks\\\": [\\n    \\\"Because 2 mol NaOH react per 1 mol H2SO4, the acid concentration should be about half the base concentration when similar volumes are used.\\\",\\n    \\\"Here base volume (23.40 cm3) is slightly smaller than acid volume (25.00 cm3), so acid concentration slightly less than 0.150/2 = 0.075 mol dm-3; 0.0702 fits.\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",

For CH4 + 2O2 → CO2 + 2H2O: bonds broken are 4×(C–H) from CH4 and 2×(O=O) from 2O2. Broken energy = 4×413 + 2×498 = 1652 + 996 = 2648 kJ mol-1. Bonds formed are 2×(C=O in CO2) in CO2 and 4×(O–H) in 2H2O (each H2O has two O–H bonds). Formed energy = 2×805 + 4×463 = 1610 + 1852 = 3462 kJ mol-1. Therefore ΔH = 2648 − 3462 = −814 kJ mol-1 (exothermic, as expected for combustion).\\\",\\n  \\\"key_equations\\\": [\\n    \\\"ΔH = Σ(bonds broken) − Σ(bonds formed)\\\",\\n    \\\"Bonds broken: 4(C–H) + 2(O=O)\\\",\\n    \\\"Bonds formed: 2(C=O) + 4(O–H)\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"line_refs\\\": [\\n    \\\"L44\\\",\\n    \\\"L45\\\",\\n    \\\"L46\\\",\\n    \\\"L47\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"checks\\\": [\\n    \\\"Combustion should be exothermic, so ΔH should be negative; −814 kJ mol-1 satisfies this.\\\",\\n    \\\"Bond counting check: CH4 has 4 C–H bonds; 2O2 contains 2 O=O bonds; products form 2 C=O and 4 O–H bonds.\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",

Calculate charge passed using Q = I×t: Q = 1.50 A × 1800 s = 2700 C. The Faraday constant is F = 96,500 C mol-1, so moles of electrons transferred is n(e−) = Q/F = 2700/96500 = 0.02798 mol e−. Copper(II) ions require 2 electrons per Cu atom deposited, so n(Cu) = 0.02798/2 = 0.01399 mol. Using the molar mass of Cu (63.55 g mol-1), mass deposited = n×Mr = 0.01399 × 63.55 = 0.8889 g ≈ 0.889 g.\\\",\\n  \\\"key_equations\\\": [\\n    \\\"Q = I × t\\\",\\n    \\\"n(e−) = Q / F (from F in C mol−1)\\\",\\n    \\\"n(Cu) = n(e−)/2\\\",\\n    \\\"m = n × Mr\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"line_refs\\\": [\\n    \\\"L51\\\",\\n    \\\"L17\\\",\\n    \\\"L19\\\",\\n    \\\"L24\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"checks\\\": [\\n    \\\"If current or time increased, Q would increase and more Cu would be deposited; the direct proportionality matches Q = It.\\\",\\n    \\\"Order-of-magnitude: 2700 C is ~0.028 mol e−; halving gives ~0.014 mol Cu; at ~64 g/mol this is just under 1 g, consistent with 0.889 g.\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",
  "call_id": "call_rY4lAWADdKdfgWwTta4ahLTq",

[NO2] = 0.180 mol / 2.00 dm3 = 0.0900 mol dm-3. [N2O4] = 0.220 mol / 2.00 dm3 = 0.110 mol dm-3. Use Kc = [NO2]^2 / [N2O4]. Substitute: Kc = (0.0900)^2 / 0.110 = 0.00810 / 0.110 = 0.0736 (dimensionless).\\\",\\n  \\\"key_equations\\\": [\\n    \\\"Kc = [NO2]^2 / [N2O4]\\\",\\n    \\\"[X] = moles(X) / volume\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"line_refs\\\": [\\n    \\\"L20\\\",\\n    \\\"L56\\\",\\n    \\\"L57\\\",\\n    \\\"L58\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"checks\\\": [\\n    \\\"Both concentrations are < 0.2/2 = 0.1 mol dm-3 scale, so Kc should be around (0.09^2)/0.11 ≈ 0.07, matching.\\\",\\n    \\\"If [NO2] were higher relative to [N2O4], Kc would increase; squaring [NO2] makes this sensitivity clear.\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",
  "call_id": "call_i1myXxa3lxQ21XEiC8Dc4ohc",
  "name": "write_file",
  "parsed_arguments": null

  },
  "method": "First find the mass of calcium carbonate in the impure limestone: m(CaCO3) = 5.00 g × 0.840 = 4.20 g. Next calculate moles using n = m/Mr. From the atomic data, Mr(CaCO3) = 40.1 + 12.0 + 3×16.0 = 100.1, so n(CaCO3) = 4.20/100.1 = 0.04196 mol ≈ 0.0420 mol. From the balanced equation CaCO3 + 2HCl → CaCl2 + CO2 + H2O, 1 mol CaCO3 produces 1 mol CO2, so n(CO2) = 0.0420 mol. Mr(CO2) = 12.0 + 2×16.0 = 44.0, so mass of CO2 = n×Mr = 0.0420 × 44.0 = 1.85 g (maximum, since acid is in excess).",
  "key_equations": [
    "n = m / Mr",
    "m(CaCO3) = sample mass × (percent/100)",
    "1 mol CaCO3 → 1 mol CO2 (from balanced equation)",

  ]
}

{

  "method": "Calculate moles of NaOH used: convert volume to dm3, V(NaOH) = 23.40 cm3 = 0.02340 dm3. Then n(NaOH) = c×V = 0.150 mol dm-3 × 0.02340 dm3 = 0.00351 mol. Use the balanced equation H2SO4 + 2NaOH → Na2SO4 + 2H2O: 2 mol NaOH neutralize 1 mol H2SO4, so n(H2SO4) = 0.00351/2 = 0.001755 mol. Convert acid volume: V(H2SO4) = 25.00 cm3 = 0.02500 dm3. Finally c(H2SO4) = n/V = 0.001755 / 0.02500 = 0.0702 mol dm-3.",
  "key_equations": [
    "c = n / V",
    "n = c × V",
    "n(H2SO4) = n(NaOH)/2 (from stoichiometry)"

}

{

    "value": -814,
    "units": "kJ mol-1",
    "precision_note": "Reported to 3 s.f.; value is an estimate because mean bond energies are used."
  },
  "method": "Use ΔH = Σ(bonds broken) − Σ(bonds formed). For CH4 + 2O2 → CO2 + 2H2O: bonds broken are 4×(C–H) from CH4 and 2×(O=O) from 2O2. Broken energy = 4×413 + 2×498 = 1652 + 996 = 2648 kJ mol-1. Bonds formed are 2×(C=O in CO2) in CO2 and 4×(O–H) in 2H2O (each H2O has two O–H bonds). Formed energy = 2×805 + 4×463 = 1610 + 1852 = 3462 kJ mol-1. Therefore ΔH = 2648 − 3462 = −814 kJ mol-1 (exothermic, as expected for combustion).",
  "key_equations": [
    "ΔH = Σ(bonds broken) − Σ(bonds formed)",

  ]
}

{
  "problem_id": "P05",

  "method": "Convert time to seconds: 30.0 min × 60 = 1800 s. Calculate charge passed using Q = I×t: Q = 1.50 A × 1800 s = 2700 C. The Faraday constant is F = 96,500 C mol-1, so moles of electrons transferred is n(e−) = Q/F = 2700/96500 = 0.02798 mol e−. Copper(II) ions require 2 electrons per Cu atom deposited, so n(Cu) = 0.02798/2 = 0.01399 mol. Using the molar mass of Cu (63.55 g mol-1), mass deposited = n×Mr = 0.01399 × 63.55 = 0.8889 g ≈ 0.889 g.",

  ]
}
